_IfvknItB_tjTU0lYqZRSA.text: Warm and wonderful experience at Jose tonight. The place was packed, but the hostess made sure we had a place to stand so that we could order drinks while waiting for a place to sit down. Delicious tapas, great service, everything first rate. Pablo, our waiter, was a jewel.

ILUoyCTkdNZvU0ZHhmLCIA.text: The sherry selection and tapas in this place is fantastic (even if you don't normally drink sherry give it a go here, you might be pleasantly surprised). The atmosphere is vibrant and even though it's small and almost always rammed, it never feels oppressive or overcrowded - the staff do a good job of keeping the numbers just right. Even better in the cold winter months. Brilliant.

j172Mf7MqVMXpai3UiBN2Q.text: After hearing so many good things about this place from friends and reviews we decided to give it a try. We got here just after 7pm on a Thursday evening - it was unbelievably busy! We were lucky to get a standing spot in a corner by one of the bar tables (there were hardly any seats). Between the 4 of us, we shared - meatballs, padron peppers, 2x tomato bread, patatas bravas, prawns, veg stew, tortilla, ham croquetas, squid. The best dish was the squid...the rest were OK. There were just too many people in such a tiny space, and on a warm evening, it got to the point where it was almost unbearable as there is no A/C or any ventilation at all other than the door that was left open. We had to finish our food quickly and breathed a huge sigh a relief the moment we left the bar and had some fresh air.

m-lFQip9G1VYMWjbIiULYg.text: Neighbours. Everybody needs good neighbours...or so they say on Ramsey St. And it's no different here on Bermondsey St, with the latest addition to the already thriving foodie neighbourhood (Zucca and Garrison are both on the same street) - we welcome José; a Sherry and Tapas bar co-owned by ex Brindisia Spanish chef José Pizarro and Hervé Durochat, formerly of Hakkasan and the Soho House Group. The food menu is concise with the usual suspects like Tortilla, Patatas Bravas and Jamon Ibérico, along with a daily changing market-menu (the specials), dependent on whatever is fresh at the market that morning. We ordered the special of grilled sardines (£5), and pork neck (£8), served medium rare instead. Both were incredibly tasty, simply cooked with a drizzle of olive oil, yet perfectly seasoned. The Patatas Bravas (£2.50) were quite possibly the best I've had..definitely in London anyway. Crispy on the outside and gorgeously fluffy on the inside, served with a fresh, heavenly dollop of aioli on top. The Jamon Ibérico croquettes were good, but at £6 for some pequeñas bolas, I could have easily gone without. The vibe is great though. Buzzing, yet cosy, reminiscent of the tapas bars in Barcelona's La Boqueria markets. The arrival of José to the neighbourhood is perfectly timed, especially for the summer months ahead. Get there as soon as you can! Olé For full review and pictures, please go to gourmetbelly.wordpress.c…

liTMqp9Gu_UY68zcXsFzng.text: The best tapas I've had in Ldn! Their wines are great too. Really wonderful, quality food. The price is not cheap, but you'll be very satisfied.

ifVF0FE62y2kf4SMOaOXGg.text: Really great tapas! The seafood a la plancha is succulent and full-flavored. The space is intimate and simply decorated. If I lived in London I'd eat here often.

bpSArDjAb3ZuoHYMSAmo4A.text: Great good great little ambience . Can be tricky to get in but that's always a good sign.well worth checking out one Saturday afternoon, after a visit to Maltby street market.

cUcbPfDY2fBoB4tPB33HYw.text: Great little place for some tapas and sherry!  We loved all the dishes even the simple but delicious Pan con Tomate.  Loved your demo at the Tapas Fantastica yesterday!

GV1JJpL-bubf2E1WMqZdRg.text: We'd finally hit summer. Friday night spent lolling outside the pub and a perky Saturday of sun and fun with walks wearing shirt and no jumper. A continental day ended appropriately with a hoped for but unscheduled aperitif stop in Bermondsey tapas joint du jour Jose. Owned eponymously by Jose 'Brindisa' Pizarro and garrulous business partner front of house expert Herve, it's finishing the job that neighbour (and final dinner destination) Zucca kick started and making Bermondsey, Street at least, a real foodie destination. I have a slight problem with tapas restaurants out of their native environments, and it's that you can't crawl. The joy of tapas for me comes with a gleeful bowl around the neighbourhood and a bite and a glass in each joint. Moderation, exercise and a pub crawl in one. With a little help from Herve, we may have cracked it. Prior to dinner and after a long warm walk, I was ready for a glass of something dry and crisp and cold. I steered us into Jose, keen to have a gander. The white tiled space focussed around the marble slab bar feels uncharacteristically out of place in South London, the heat emanating from it even more so. A combination of the small room, a large stove surrounded by Jose and his brigade, no air con and a sunny day meant I nearly lost the others at the first hurdle. The place was packed, no more than 25 in there, but it's enough not to want to be there when it's busier. No reservations means that like Spuntino you're going to have to come early, or be prepared to wait. As Herve explained, they're not aiming for the (London) bridge and tunnel crowd but hoping to add something to a great little local scene prior to opening larger restaurant Pizarro later in the year.I sucked down deliciously dry sherry while we gorged, an early doors licensing quirk meant no booze without food, on a couple of the delicious tapa from behind the counter. We grabbed a couple of plates judging they would suffice as starters. Sea fresh boquerones, juicy white anchovies, came in a light and sweet seasoned cava vinegar, Murcian speciality pisto, a simple full flavoured Spanish version of ratatouille, came with a perfectly fried duck's egg. Giant yolk flecked with salt looming over the the plate reminding us of the late spring sun. Despite the specials board (cruelly featuring crab and basil croquettes the next day) you'd struggle to make a full meal out of the place, but that's partly the point. Grab a couple of plates, and move on. We admitted to Herve that we were going on to Zucca for our mains; "there you go then! There's your tapas crawl.. start here, mains at Zucca and then on to Village East for a cocktail or dessert." Tapas crawl, Bermondsey style.

LRP9m8hDjZJLMqaV_92ZIg.text: What does Tapas mean to you or to anyone? Small plates of food served with a drink? It's not just the food. Obviously the food is good. For me, it's the food and everything else that goes with. If you have been to Spain, You will tend to notice, how the Spaniard just sit around with vin and cervecas and their tapas, chatting away with no worries of everything that's happening around them.I always been a great lover of cultures who sits down and spends time to enjoy the food and the company they are with. It saddens me something that we do not have this culture in London. Even in Asia, even how very over productive they are, time is essential for making money. They still take time to have their lunches. A proper lunch at most time with friends or even just on their own. In London, having an hour break seems a sort of guilty pleasure that you're forbidden to enjoy.I want to introduce, one of my favourite tapas places in London. The food is good, but what I like about it is, it feels I just stepped into a tapas place in Spain. No reservation says Jose. Yeap, Jose's tapas bar. This little tapas place in Bermondsey brings me back to times good times in Spain. Wine barrels as table tops, simple tapas dishes, and all good Spanish wine by the glass. I went to Jose yesterday, had a few tapas and drinks over long chats on a summer's day (in London). It was perfect. Simple Spanish food and culture. A good way to experience Spain in London. I highly recommend Jose for exactly what I said. SIMPLE SPANISH CULTURE!!!thehungrybea.com

RsgigKzeV9SmNUgAcCE4ng.text: The food is awesome. (I could give 4.5 stars for the food.) This place is always very packed c6-9pm and sometimes you have to wait a good half an hour around the door sipping their wine. Standing and eating tapas around one of the barrels is not too bad but it's better to be seated at the bar.

EzECp_sGKx1FLq5939hCJw.text: After many months of waiting we finally got round to making a long overdue visit to Jose on Saturday. Having walked past the tiny corner bar many times, and seen the crowds hopefully waiting for a bit of space to free up inside, we were well aware that we would need to arrive early if we wanted to avoid queuing in the snow. We turned up just before 6pm and were lucky to get a couple of stools by the window facing Morocco Street. If you haven't had the pleasure of visiting Jose it's probably worth pointing out that this is a bar not a restaurant and it's more than likely that you will be spending your evening propping up the bar or a strategically placed barrel. The sherry list looked very inviting and after a bit of chat with the friendly and informative staff we started our evening off with a glass of the Manzanilla Pastrana for me and the Puerto Fino for B. When combined with a plate of hot, salty padron peppers this is possibly the perfect way to get the appetite up and running. The menu covers all the tapas classics and is supplemented by an ever changing selection of daily specials chalked up on a blackboard behind the bar. The prices are pretty reasonable and there is plenty to stimulate even the most jaded of palates. We had a good run at both the daily specials and the normal menu; ordering a couple of plates at a time and then adding a few more later. If there are only two of you eating it's quite easy to get carried away and seriously over order!!! Stand out dishes were the sweet chilli prawns which were just divine, the hake with allioli and some very tasty meatballs. The wine list was well put together with plenty of good things to drink without breaking the bank. We had a bottle of the Casa Maria Verdejo (£18) which went down very well and was a good accompaniment to the fish dishes. By the time we were thinking about dessert it was after 8pm and London's first snow of the year was coming down thick and fast. Bermondsey Street was looking very picturesque, but sensing looming trouble with the rail network we decided to make a hasty exit well pleased with a lovely evening at Jose and vowing to come back for a long lunch next month. Highly recommended for both the food and quality of service.

photos.caption: Photo of Jose - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Jose - London, United Kingdom

2trqBLKACZkSWmhpSFvAPg.text: With the weather being so warm and lovely on Sunday. M and I decided to pop down to south london and has a Tapas lunch. José sprung to mind. A popular Tapas bar that has been recommended by many critics and foodie alike. As it is located in Bermondsey, which is not too far from us. This is perfect. First impression upon approaching the bar is that this is, without a doubt, a Tapas bar. It occupied a tiny corner of the street. From the outside, A charming, mahogany exterior with fuss-free decor. It was so subtle that we nearly walked past it without knowing. Once entered, we were immediately transport into a cosy, slightly Hispanic ambiance. The decorative tile, juxtaposed with exposed brick walls and the industrial steel pillar and beam. Wooden flooring and ceiling and a strategically place wooden barrel complete this unassuming bar. The exposed kitchen is a welcome feature. The aroma exudes from it when the chef were cooking were simply intoxicating. It was already busy when we got here at around 2 o'clock. The buzzing crowd further add to this sociable Spanish charm. We were first ushered to the table right by the kitchen where we had to stand by the friendly matron'd but a couple paid up and left while we were pondering on the menu. So we were swiftly moved to the corner where the much sought after stools were available. We ordered a selection from the menu as well as a few from the chalkboard behind the bar. This apparently are the daily specials that changes everyday according to what's fresh and available in the market. The wine arrived not long after. The red Decenio Cranza Rioja was an excellent choice. It was oaky and fruity, with a light liquorice and perhaps vanilla aftertaste. Read more on feasttotheworld.com/2012…

photos.caption: Photo of Jose - London, United Kingdom

C5ZQETVblG7867or9yiX-Q.text: Simple, well prepared, quality food. Great little venue and menu. Only downside? I know it sound silly but can't quite get over the Italians working in a Spanish bar. They've got the wrong attitude pushing side orders, extra drinks and tips and their accent/gesturing grates. Bring back the Spaniards and it would be a 5

rQVr1-LpNLZSIps2M7tZyQ.text: Must go.Food couldn't have been better and service was attentive and helpful.  A definite stop on our next trip.

xJ-t27WOejEMIAJQ3AR_Aw.text: There are a few European, food culture trends that need to be exported to the US, like, now. Besides Roman coffee bars and Danish smorrebrod, the standing room-only, Spanish tapas bar is a must. And while I wait for these things to never happen, I'm so happy I can find it here. Because, ya know, schlepping to Spain for tapas isn't always feasible... if I could export Europe's close geographical quarters to the US, I would do that, too. The food is traditional with small plates of patatas bravas, boquerones, and croquetas all being worthy of a try. I also really enjoy the Iberico ham selection. I haven't partaken in any of the sherries yet, as I can't help but gulp down the ice cold, Andalucian staple, Alhambra cerveza that they keep on tap. It makes a great date spot, if only for the fact that the crowding gives you an excuse to stand (what would be considered uncomfortably close in other settings) to the other person. For a little more privacy try to angle for a spot at the counter on the windows. And while it's not a great area for overall entertainment, it is a nice walk up to Tower Bridge in the evening. Now if only I didn't have to come all the way from West London to enjoy it!

AoEj9Osf8clEsvYDmYWr8Q.text: This place is tucked in the Bermondsey neighborhood but when you walk inside it feels like you've walked into a typical tapas bar in Barcelona for reasonable prices. We ordered patatas bravas, the egg dish, shrimp, and delicious croquetas. + they gave us sparkling water. Next time I'll get the Barcelona beer!

V697kA5M9btJsgyVaazQTw.text: Fantastic! Get here early for lunch, there must only be about 15 places to sit and it is (rightly) popular.

-TKOzUHoPs2_WOex4GcKdg.text: Finally!! I got to check out Jose bc we got in!! This tiny place is a great way to meet friends for tapas and drinks. At first we didn't know where to sit but a nice gentleman approached us and had us sit at the counter area. Me and my friends had cava and ordered Jamon Iberia, which was delicious. The pan con tomato I was in love with - way better than even what I had in Barcelona!We ordered the croquettes, which was creamy and delicious. We also had the chili prawns and razor clams - so nicely flavored and fresh.  Wasn't cheap but I am SO coming back!!

nodPUogQg_D57wby3HM7dA.text: Oh, yum. En route to Logan Airport at 5 am for an early flight to London, I shot a friend I hadn't seen in years a Facebook message to see if she was still living in the UK and could possibly meet. She replied that she'd be going on holiday, but could meet for dinner on my first full day in London. Despite jet lag followed by a 9-hour work day, I offered to travel far and wide to her favorite restaurant to get the best experience possible. This was the girl who taste-tested every single Maredo location in Berlin with me and made the hour U-bahn ride to my favorite czech beer garden so I could eat unidentified meat when she was still vegetarian. But, I digress.One of my friend's favorite dining spots in Bermondsey is José, a tiny, dimly-lit tapas restaurant where you often eat standing up since there are maybe 8 seats at the bar. I'd guess the capacity of the whole place is 40. I was super starving after eating only a pret sandwich and dessert bar all day, but agreed that starting with a beer then splitting a bottle of wine with her and her husband was a good idea. We then proceeded to order a handful of small plates--a fatty meat and some fish dishes come to memory. It was kind of a blur, but the food was all good. Oh yeah, there were some chili-soaked prawns. Yum. What I really remember was dessert--a shot glass of a salty chocolate fudge with olive oil. Go to José for that, if nothing else. So good.

B2rb3klcvU_JSzkFKRxDNw.text: It was a short wait as we arrived just before 7pm on a weeknight. Somehow made the food even better. Tomato bread and garlicky prawns were super tasty. Will definitely be back to try their other dishes and some more sherry!

gVoqGDPEbmoOmc5AI0h5jw.text: José is an incredible tapas bar located in the middle of Bermondsey Street.  Although it is very small and almost impossible at times to get in, it really is worth the wait. The tapas are very simple yet wonderful (not as inventive as the ones from Pizarro, the owner's other restaurant down the street).  My favorite dishes are the croquetas And pan con tomate.  I love Jose and would love to go again soon.

QW2pKuGGytlxBF1fP_ZsZw.text: This place has everything. It's small, but perfectly formed! Great atmosphere, fantastic service, lurverly food and yummy wine! I turned up about 20 minutes after my dear friend, who was bodily holding a seat for me! To their credit, although the place was packed and a line forming outside, the staff were happy to let him sit and drink and take up two stools until I arrived. They even then sorted out a little tussle that I had to have with another customer over who should have custody of said stool! They gave her another place and we were both happy. The menu is written up on boards behind the cooking area - where you can see all that goes on with the preparation of your food. I like that! I'm not germaphobic at all, but I do like a nice clean kitchen! As always happens with tapas we ordered loads and then realised that we had gone overboard when we thought we had finished and even more turned up! They were brilliant about the timing - only giving us a couple of plates at any one time. We had: Tomato bread (actually very crusty bread soaked in tomato juice. very flavourful.)Iberico ham (deep colour and flavour, absolutely stunning, went very well on top of the bread)Croquetas (not my cup of tea - too creamy inside, but my friend LOVED them!) Hake (actually a bit like an upmarket bit of chip shop fish)Clams in white wine sauce (beautiful!)Prawns in chilli (HUGE! More like small lobsters in chilli!) And the best red wine I have had in quite a while! It was absolutely scrummy! This was enough to completely stuff two people with usually very healthy appetites! For the record, the wine (three glasses!) I had was the 2009 Juan Gil SIlver Label, Monastrel, Jumilla at 8.5 quid a glass. That's more than I usually like to pay, but it was worth it. Recommended by the rather sexy waiter, it was the perfect red wine to accompany tapas. It was smooth, fruity and delicious. I think I have found my new favourite little place in Bermondsey!

Nxj4LQFCvxwU9WKVeRLdFA.text: The place is tiny and very packed. The waiters are really helpful and make every effort to find you a small spot to "sit" down. Overall it as a very good atmosphere. The food also stands up. The Jamón ibérico is great, the tomato bread is delicate and the meatballs were amazing with the spicy tomato sauce. Another highlight was the grilled Chorizo. So overall food was really good. The wine wasn't the best, there is some room for improvement there. A negative point are the prices. Tapas cost around £ 8 in average. In total our bill for 2 with only two glasses of wine came to £ 85 with tips. For the type of location and the food this seemed a bit steep, even for London.

q38nlCpi4soz7sJlohuD7Q.text: Cute, really yummy, affordable, cozy, good service (they were really nice, warm and accommodating). Excellent spot!

sddiZSC8TXp9b9zeWHpkVA.text: Tapas time! I love me some tapas as it's a great excuse to order lots of different dishes without looking moronic. Add to that some wine or sherry and you've got a winner.I've been wanting to go to Jose for ages since a) it's just up my street, and b) the smells coming for it have been mouthwatering. Unfortunately, it always seems to be rammed after work or for most of the day on the weekend. Luckily, we were told we could head off around 2pm on the 23rd (some benefits for working over the Christmas season when most of London has gone) so when I got a text about lunch from Tracy L, I immediately opted for this little cosy place.As it was pretty empty, we immediately were seated at the bar type area. First strange thing: they don't do tap water, only still or sparkling from their fancy filter system. It's not expensive, but just a bit odd when you ask for tap water and they say they don't have taps. Go figure.We started with pardon peppers, chilli garlic prawns, and squid in a garlic aioli. To whet our whistle so to speak, we were recommended a pale manzanilla sherry. The pardon peppers were perfect with large crystals of sea salt enhancing their otherwise mild flavour. They retained  bit of crunch and went down a treat. The chilli garlic prawns were massive and perfectly cooked although I felt the marinade was a bit lacking in depth. The squid in garlic aioli with a green chilli sauce was fantastic and I could have happily eaten just that. In fact we asked for extra bread to dip into the sauce and kept munching away. The sherry was a bit of a let down with a flat flavour and was a lot drier than I expected. It was more a dry white wine than anything sherry-like.The rain was pounding down, so we opted for another glass of sherry (this time recommended by a very flirtatious waiter) which was a oloroso sherry which was darker in colour and more on the sweeter side. This was far better (to my tastes) as it had a rich slightly chocolatey taste with a dark red fruit (think ripe plums) body and a lingering sweet after taste. To go with our food, we tried a plate of their Iberian ham. Contrary to most ham plates, this was heavy on the fat which was a bit too slick to eat easily although the ham itself was rich and flavourful with the sought after sharp meaty taste.Finally, no epic meal would be complete without dessert, and a chocolate pot seemed just the ticket. This was phenomenal. I'm not stranger to chocolate and have been known to devour whole dessert menus in a single sitting. The Spanish version of the chocolate pot (at least as far as Jose is concerned) is less rich and bitter than the French chocolate pot and runs more towards a mousse consistency. This one was silky smooth, creamy, with heavy drumbeats of dark tied nicely with the melody of milk. It was so good Tracy and I fought to scrape the bowl clean. In hindsight we should have just ordered another one.The place is a tad pricey with our feast for two running around £60-70. But I suppose given the quality and location it isn't that unreasonable.Jose has just opened a new restaurant on the street called Pizarro. Guess where I'll be eating next?

x_nAXYIKsdYj1EdKney_SQ.text: This place is amazing.  Has a great atmosphere, the staff are super attentive without being invasive and the food is phenomenal.  Try everything.  Some of the dishes are better than others but that's just down to preferences. It can get busy but even if there is a queue out the door (as they don't take bookings), don't let that put you off as the staff are great at managing the space.  Jose is the more informal restaurant with Pizzaro (just down the road) the more formal one.  But the food is great at both and so it's really down to what sort of atmosphere you want.  Jose is a bit more lively as it's more bar like.

ufdx6SVc5amODVZ-KQuh6Q.text: I have had this place on my list forever but knew I needed to find a time when we could rock up and get a spot.  That was about 6pm on a Wed eve and we were able to grab seats at a beautiful marble bar facing the window.  It was a great spot because we could have a conversation--it wasn't too noisy and despite the fact we were a bit nudged in the corner our waiter really looked after us.  (NOTE:  service is not included so don't forget to tip if you do go and get great service as we did).  The wine was fab.  I was impressed with the tortilla (not as good as Barrafina but probably comes in second on the tortilla ranking).  Croquetas were a spicy spinach--surprising but good.  Gem salad with walnuts and blue cheese was yummy and the Iberian pork was good.  The standout was the asparagus (in season) with romenesco sauce and jamon.  I loved the vibe, the food and the wine.  I felt like I was in Spain.  Salud!

WbUmPEShMYUGrGoVza-Pew.text: This might just be the best tapas you can get your hands on outside of Spain. Too bad it's so small. It easily gets crowded and without being able to reserve any of the few tables they have, be prepared to wait for a while. It is worth the wait though, and they are quick to serve so order in some ham while socializing (the face to face type)

vbS278flRmCmdzQ4ha2ROg.text: Met my friend here a few nights ago, he got there first, ordered a beer and was informed he had to order food as well. He explained he was waiting and would order when I arrived, but they insisted. Ridiculous, it's not even a restaurant, but a tapas bar, with tiny tables.When I arrived, I ordered a padron peppers and a glass of wine; prices start at an expensive £5.50 a glass, and quickly go up. Peppers were average, stingy portion.When we went to have a cigarette, we were told to stand on the other side of the street. All this coupled with a small, crowded, noisy room. I will not be going back.

9QGGVQ3hUVC73QBSkcn64A.text: Since I'm a diehard fan of tapas, I'm very reluctant to go somewhere in London where it's not done right. And there's a lot of pretentious, snooty tapas bars in London and that's not what real tapas are about. It's the low-key, friendly atmosphere and vibrant, energetic bustle that make a tapas bar great, and Jose is all that. We went on a Friday evening and it was really packed. So we waited for seats to free up by standing, and eventually we started ordering because inevitably you get hungry as the wait can be very long (but that's how they do it in Spain, so I shouldn't be complaining). Everything was delicious. The quality was impeccable.The wine selection also went very well with the food... we got a bottle and finished it pretty quickly. And it's great to stand/sit by the large windows and gaze out onto the humble streets of Bermondsey. But the bill was not as humble (unlike Spain) so can't go here all the time, but was definitely a great experience!Note that you cannot add tip on your card so be prepared to bring some cash so you can properly tip the waiters.

FIaPPAB7Edb9Na9l9aQtlQ.text: I absolutely loved this place. We came here randomly after looking for a place to eat near Bourough and so glad we did. The place is small and was absolutely packed which is a good sign. The man running the show was really nice - gave us a place to stand and asked if we wanted any drinks while we waited for a place to sit. Once we got a spot, the service was quick and the food was amazing. Absolutely no complaints and everything we had was delightful. Can not wait to go back.

VH4888NrpHwIjhvHbKWPew.text: Visited Jose's on a stifling late summer day. It was lunch time, midday in fact, as I'd heard that there is very little space when busy. This was a great move as we got to sit at the window and watch the world go by. There are no tables just ledges or barrels to place your food/drinks on.I ordered cava to drink which was very . Food consisted of bread and oil, tomato salad, clams and morels. There was a slight slip with out order as we had actually ordered razor clams but got clams but was not a problem. The food was moreish and simple. The real star was actually the tomato salad which consisted of the tastiest tomatoes I've had in London (I hope they can be sourced in Borough market!)I will certainly be visiting Jose's again but don't fancy going when it's busy as I like to sit down when eating.

yM-mQ4uVobpn3yKXkNPefQ.text: The tapas was good (as good as many places that are now dotted around London like Polpo etc) but the dining experience is unpleasant - cramped, rushed, squeezed, handbag on hooks right where you legs should go, coat pegs not near where you're be sitting, uncomfortable stools. Just not enjoyable to feel like that, regardless that there are some good dishes.

ldBALGxALk7D1_AWVS_hqQ.text: This might be best tapas restaurant I've tried outside of Spain (I think it might even surpass Barrafina). Everything here was fresh and light on the oil, which is soooo important, because sometimes I feel like tapas are completely smothered in oil and you miss the flavors.We ordered the below and loved everything! The wine selection is also amazing. Everyone's really laid back here and it was completely packed but the atmosphere was cozy.SeabreamPatatas BravasTortillaBoquerones en Vinagre (SO GOOD)Padron PeppersPork belly

x-lp_unKfJ6FU-9BHEv4RA.text: This was great. I spent a couple of hours there on a Tuesday eve. The first couple of hours by myself, enjoying delicious  but slightly chewy ham, and the best grilled pork I've ever had, together with some stellar spanish wine. Then a friend joined up, and we proceeded to try out a pile of other dishes, with the braised octopus probably being the stand-out. This place was very solid; delicious and friendly. A wee bit crowded (as you would expect from a tapas bar), and more classic than modern/innovative dishes, but I'll definitely come back next time I'm in the neighbourhood.

AQhQ9VgRbfhmnjArTGlzFw.text: Wow. Wow... Wow. I have never been to this part of London hidden away in some side streets just next to the river this is an excellent spot! The yelp map pinpoints this restaurant incorrectly however, the restaurant is just a bit further down the road and can be found on the corner of the road. Going in here with my friend it was not at all what I expected, an intimate bench with just enough room to fit your food and wine on was a smart choice instead of tables to make the most of the limited room in a very small restaurant. The staff are very good at getting to you and getting your food quickly. The tapas here is incredible. We ordered the omelette, chorizo, pumpkin, the filet of beef. These were all incredible It makes me want to go back this week. I also had a very special bottle of Spanish Rose which turned out to be very good indeed.

HYnisBHroXo9t6DCNOtf5A.text: Fantastic Taps bar, the meats are incredible, the octopus awesome, green peppers great. It was all really good. Little cosy, smallish the place, but it makes up with its flavours!

uydK94uvxgx_A5DmUtgubg.text: wow this place is worth the effort to get too.  thanks to Boris bikes its less than 10mts from london bridge.   I've never been to this part of Bermondsey Street, but its has a local village feel to it with some other excellent looking bars to try.We arrived at Jose around 8pm on Saturday night and the place was jam packed and seemed almost as many people waiting for tables.  The waiter told us to order drinks while we waited and  we managed to get a table before our first round was finished.  i normally use yelp/foursquare reviews for dish tips/suggestions but apparently they change their menu quite often so this didnt help us too much.  however, our waiter had such passion for the food that he took the time to explain all the dishes including the farms/locations where some of their ingredient were acquired.  we ordered the spicy prawns, tomato bread, sliced beef fillets cooked very rare and jersey potatoes with 2 styles of sauces.   wow all the dishes were amazing and the ingredients very well balanced.   and to top all that off all 4 plates and 2 rounds of drinks came to about £45.  absolute bargain for the quality of the food and drinks we had!

E_8fn-EalxD9uJCwprp8TA.text: I finally managed to get a table at this place which is so small and so popular that sometimes you feel it's not worth attempted to go intoI have to say the food is just extraordinary...everything on the menu is just normal tapas but the way they do it is just so delicious .... I recommend the patatas Bravas, jamon Iberico and hake...all just so delicious The problem with this place is that you aren't going to sit down or have a comfortable meal... It's always going to be crowded and intense ...it's a bar essentially with tapas ... But the food just makes up for it as does the service Highly recommended but not a place to relax, just to have good Spanish food

0qAqOsCfi5bdRxDUo-qWvA.text: They have authentic Iberican ham. The Iberico Jamon (shaved aged pork shoulder) is excellent. The Pluma Iberica (pork flank cooked rare - a rare find outside of Spain) is amazing. Nice wine list.Great food; great wine; fantastic service especially for London. A must visit. Will come again.

6TtAlZ5TAHlZep6QFjeDZg.text: The best Spanish food I've had outside of Spain and possibly in Spain! Me and my husband shared about 4 tapas and all of them were out of this world. Beautiful little place in a lovely location. Will be back when I visit London again!

photos.caption: Photo of Jose - London, United Kingdom

dWv63xdeXg0EZ-iuYQdt9g.text: Great Tapas menu and wine list.  We tried the jamon Ibérica, croquetas, pluma, cheese plate, tortilla and calamares.  Everything was delicious.  This place is small, but very lively.  The host tries his best to get you in to a good spot.  If another opens, he will ask if you want to move :-).  The wait staff is stupendous.

photos.caption: Photo of Jose - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Jose - London, United Kingdom. It's where to be for happy hour. Their tapas are to die for. Great Spanish wines and beer available too. Lively atmosphere

fbz6Hm99rgc2ED9BvtElJQ.text: I decided to bring my friend to Jose because she's a huge fan of Brindisa's tapas for Sunday brunch - it was really nice to be able to sit at one of the bar tables for once! The food is impeccable. We ordered a large amount of food for two - patatas bravas, chorizo with toast, iberica pluma, tortilla, razor clams etc. Although everything seems simple and easy to make - iberica pluma's seared pork, and the razor clams were topped with chorizo, every dish was packed with flavour. My favourites had to be the chorizo and the razor clams - surprisingly not too heavy, and so addictive. The tortilla is a massive slice of potato-eggy goodness. Yum.One downside though was that the pork was drowning in olive oil. I love olive oil, but  the pork was literally sitting in a pool of olive oil...not exactly appetising but the pork was really really good. During peak hours it's definitely packed and you'll find yourself pushing/being pushed around a bit, but that's all part of the atmosphere of a tapas bar! Definitely one of the best places in London for tapas. Bermondsey's a real food heaven.

photos.caption: Photo of Jose - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Jose - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Jose - London, United Kingdom

sLHNkxZYyCe_mHjxma7FJw.text: We lucked out with the place not being crowded on a January Saturday night! It was lively when we arrived, and then cleared out a bit at the end of the evening and was quite romantic...Nice easy to drink wine offerings - I liked the 2010 Viña Zorzal, Graciano, Navarra. Smooth finish.Small, but classic menu. Reminds me of when I lived in Madrid. Tomatoe bread, Jamón Ibérico, olives, etc.If I lived in the neighborhood, I would definitely hit this place every week.

E7QgNMtv4mE23xQTClXW6g.text: Today I have a special treat for you, a review of one of my favorite restaurants in London. I know I have many favorites, but José is a place with many fond memories. We used to hang out at this place almost every week. It is actually one of the first places my husband took me out on a date. What a way to steal a girls heart, offer her some Iberico pork and get her drunk on Cava. We are now married, so what else can I say than that it worked.José is the small and simple cava and tapas bar from José Pizaro who also runs a more upscale (still rather casual) restaurant called Pizarro down the road on Bermondsey Street. He was also before opening these places head chef at Tapas Brindisa. It is almost always crowded but people do not tend sit for long so often the wait is not that bad. Even if you cannot get a table immediately you can stand around and drink a glass of sparkling. The wait goes much faster with a drink in your handThere are usually three or four good sparklings (Cavas) by the glass. The wines are decently priced but perhaps not cheap, around £5-7 per glass and £30-40 per bottle (the on-going gentrification of Bermondsey Street has meant that prices are moving up). There are also nine different whites, three rosados and twelve reds by the glass. Food is excellent! The menu is not fixed, it is written on two black boards behind the bar and as things run out they are crossed off. However a few things can almost always be found there: some excellent Spanish cheeses as well as Jamon Iberico and chorizo. The Patatas Bravas, Pan con Tomate and Padron peppers are also some of my usual choices. My favorite is however, without a doubt, the flavorful Pluma Iberico (or when that is not on the menu the Secreto Iberico). Mmm, I would almost kill for that dish. All in all, I dont think I have ever been disappointed with a ny dish at Josè's.Service is always friendly and considering that it is always packed things move along smoothly. I also do like the fact that they do not automatically include service on the bill - i am not a bad tipper, but I want to make the choice myself. A tip should be an incentive to provide extra good service, not a part of the normal salary. That's just my opinion and I wish more places would do that.After years of testing the quality of food at both José and Pizarro I can conclude that the food is excellent. I think it's partly due to good quality produce, but also the skill of the chefs. It requires a special talent making simple dishes well. An important element for me is also the no-fuss quality wine list. They rotate the wines now and then so often I find new things to try.

c7PCLZ_KgAlE5jDOeP1YkA.text: Very nice food but terrible service and even offensive waiters (one of the women was particularly unpleasant). Too proud of themselves.I won't repeat, there are too many nice places out there to waste my time in bars that make you feel bad like they did.

QsITpXeD82ThMfCOypDQDw.text: By far the best tapas in town. Jamon of supreme quality and same goes for all products.Great wine list, staff is very knowledgeable and helpful if you're not accustomed with Spanish or Latin American wines.Amusing atmosphere, very vibrant and easy going! The restaurant is not big (actually very small) and you might have to wait before getting a spot but it is well worth the wait!

7Xs9jsczMJkp2hDpTX7lGQ.text: Watch out Spain!  Last year Erin and I visited Spain for two weeks and were delighted about Tapas as a cultural experience.  José does a bang up job of creating that same experience and offering it up in London.   I think Spain will continue to keep its edge on the weather, so Londoners will continue to seek out it's holiday coasts.  In the meantime and the in-between time, they can connect with Spain's fabulous flavors through José's tapas menu.Erin and I had padron peppers, thinly sliced Iberico ham (though sliced by a young dude vs. the prerequisite senior slicing the leg in Spanish tapas rooms, patatas bravas, and mackeral.  Excellent selection of spanish wines and sherries.

Topz_wmzeDuK1wH5kPOvFQ.text: This has to be one of my favorite eating establishments bar none.  The atmosphere is great,  the food is fantastic and the sherry selection is incredible.  I used to live around the corner and would visit several times a week.  Now I make a point of stopping by whenever in London. All the staff takes pride in giving you a genuine experience.

oxXTUeQh9iYUUKj40MpC2g.text: No way. In Bermondsey? No way. But the way was yes, and José has now snagged the top spot as my favourite new restaurant in London. Here's why: Cold wine. Hot tapas. Open kitchen. Exposed beams. Bar seating. Wine-barrel standing. Capacity 30. No reservations. Daily market menu. Bustling. Warm. Friendly. Lamb meatballs. Sherry. White crab croquetas. Full. Sauteed beetroot. Happy. Bermondsey.Oh, and Jose Pizarro is opening another restaurant in - you guessed it - Bermondsey in early October. Yes. Way.

photos.caption: Photo of Jose - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Jose - London, United Kingdom

PDEDZ4HSEYsYGqeAC6VmUw.text: I'm  no expert, but this place gets top marks for taking care of a hungry, tired tourist family on a drizzly Saturday evening. The Croquetas and Ibérico Pork Fillet were memorable, but I'd go back anytime given the chance.

N9xW4V-KFznGTTtz2HaK9w.text: Jose is easily one of my favourite tapas places in London. It's tiny, cosy and the food is fresh and amazing. Every time I go I can't get enough of it!!Their prawns are so fresh and you can taste and imagine the salty ocean as you take each bite. The ham on display is smoky and full of flavour. And their tortilla is a classic. Those are the classic tapas I order each time. Anything you order will be awesome there. My favourite spot is to be by the bar to see all the actions. And my final advice is to arrive early to get one of the few spots!

uHWyOU6VPizEVFFdwwQ-hg.text: My boyfriend and I have been on a bit of a mission over the summer to try out as many of the tapas restaurants in London as we could find. There are some real gems out there at the moment, but Jose is by far my favourite and earned itself a return visit on my latest trip up to the big smoke.Knowing that it doesn't take reservations, we got there well before 12 the first time, and sure enough we were seated in the table in the middle. Its a fairly tiny restaurant but they will do their best to squeeze you in, even if it looks like an impossible task on first appearances. The second occasion we got there at 2.30pm on a Saturday, but they still managed to prop us up in a little corner and later moved us to a couple of stools by the window once space became available.The menu changes on a daily basis, depending on what is available, and the dishes are listed on the blackboards behind the bar. The food is prepared and cooked in an open kitchen, a delight to a nosey foodie such as myself! The wine list is exceptional, even the house wine tasting delicious, it's far too easy to wile away a long afternoon in this cosy, vibrant restaurant.Some of the highlights from the menu are the tomato bread, pimentos de Padron, chorizo, Iberico pork cheek, hake, and mixed cheeses. Not to mention the croquetas - we have tried both the ham and the cod and both are absolutely delicious - creamy, crunchy and full of flavour! I have even purchased the cookbook so I can try and master these little delights myself!The staff are all really friendly, and it's a great opportunity to practise my Spanish.This is definitely a rustic, tradition tapas experience. If you want something a little more formal, head down the road to Jose's second restuarant Pizzaro. But if you are looking for something reminiscent of Spain, head to Jose, squeeze in to a small corner and indulge yourself for an afternoon!

0jvFLHpNZRxeB9res2xAOw.text: Jose is awesome.  My wife and I loved this place.  The environment had a hipster, but not too hipster environment.  The space was tiny, but I found this to be a feature, not a bug.  It made the whole experience very personal.Service was exceptional.  Again, I felt like I was part of a family.The location is interesting.  I used to live in the area about a decade ago and would never have expected a restaurant of this caliber a decade ago, but am really happy it is here now.Onto the food:- Jamon Iberico: Do I really need to write anything more than has already been said?  Delicious- Boquerones: I haven't had anchovies this tasty in a long time, maybe ever- Patatas bravas: Good, but probably my least favorite item- Almonds: Salty and satisfying- Excellent cheeses- Tuna steak: Oh my!  So fatty.  So savory- Chili prawns: Very enjoyable, with just a touch of heatI probably had more food than that, but I've forgotten so great was my joy.

8CS7h2UJc-5CdX9Nva9pBg.text: A small and very busy Spanish Tapas restaurant. The food is quite authentic, as compared to the tapas I've had in Spain. Only difference is that it is not as cheap as Spain, but as expected in London.It can get quite busy, and you may expect that there is standing rooms only when going at peak times. I really enjoyed the croquette, which was made with squid ink.

t8H-Hltl3hFXcijmk_G7qg.text: I lived in the area for a while and Jose was popping every time I walked past it so I knew I had to check it out!The restaurant is small and cozy, and I love that it's tucked away on a quieter corner of Bermonsey Street. I came with a friend on a Saturday late morning for brunch to avoid the wait. They serve wine all day but unfortunately it was too early for us. The food menu is displayed on two blackboards behind the open kitchen. The tapas menu is equally balanced with meat and vegetarian options and some of the names may sound very foreign but the staff are helpful and accommodating.What you need to try is the Jamon Iberico and Bermondsey Bomba! The Jamon Iberico is a great appetizer. It's super flavorful and the texture is perfect - it almost melts in your mouth. The Bermondsey Bomba is an incredibly delicious and comforting beef and potato croquette topped with housemade tomato sauce and aioli. Like its name, it's an explosion of flavors. The other things we got were impressive too! The fried goats cheese with honey is a must if your a fan of goat cheese. You also can't go wrong with the pan con tomate (toasted bread with crushed tomatoes and olive oil) - I suggest starting your meal with this. Lastly, we tried the huevos rotos - this is a fried egg served on a bed of shoe string fries. Break the egg when it comes to your table. The crispy fries are delicious dipped in the runny egg yolk. Overall, a cozy and authentic place for Spanish tapas and wine. I'm definitely coming back to try the wine next time!

5pJCf8LA3X8xIqJcKaQTbA.text: After a full day of walking around London, I stumbled in here in desperate need of food. 7 hours after my last meal, 15 miles walked, and 90 degree heat, I was famished.The restaurant is tiny, so being a solo traveler, I sat at the bar. Warning, they don't have AC and it's an open kitchen so I sweat more inside than I did walking around all day outside. Worth it though, the food was great. I had the squid with peas and mint, as well as the deep fried goat cheese with honey. They were both very good, especially the cheese. A tad pricier than I would've liked to spend, but enjoyed my meal.

photos.caption: Photo of Jose - London, United Kingdom. Deep fried goat cheese with honey
Photo of Jose - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Jose - London, United Kingdom

4DydtN_3hDCbE-xeUhQ4Hw.text: Wow, this little gem in the way from my hotel to London bridge underground station was the shit!! Amazing tapas, excellent wine list, incomparable atmosphere, lovely service, need I say more? If in London please go and enjoy yourself, I was visiting from USA and believe me I will comeback soon to savor their tapas and wine

2Bc_VnBafyLmbdN6M5RObw.text: Execellent flavored food and service. The proportions are small and the pricing is a bit step. Considering how close one is to Spain and the sourcing of good ingredients, I think they could be a little more generous with their portions. The house Grenache is delightful. Check your bill for the Optional service charge. You can decline.

hvYqK1KC-YPQZL69JZrMGA.text: On the pricey side but every tapa is a work of art. Perfect blend of textures and flavors, also nice play on hot and cold. Hands down some of the best tapas I had in a while.Still and sparkly water comes with the meal.Worth noting: the chicken liver, fried cheese and honey, and mushroom croquettes

photos.caption: Photo of Jose - London, United Kingdom. Tomato bread, croquettes and fried calamari

37gIiRX95L-xnzgAvAYokw.text: A speck of a place but I always have to stop in when in London. Delicious tapas. Their Iberico ham is DELICOUS! As in two plates for myself delicious. Most of the dishes are 7-10 pounds (Iberico 14pounds). If you are ever there at closing time - they are obsessive in their cleaning of this place!The staff is super friendly and accommodating. As I initially mentioned, it is small. That will put off a lot of people. This most recent visit we ended up standing to eat for most of our meal. The hosts do a good job of shuffling folks through.I would not recommend this place for folks with children or large groups. Good place for maybe up to 6.

GmZRw0L0hV45VQYvNP9DyQ.text: Spectacular find! I had seen the reviews for Jose's and had to check it out. I was very satisfied with my experience. The manager/ greeter was very accommodating  and helped with in selecting the perfect red! If there isn't too long of a line it's definitely worth sticking around and enjoying a glass of wine/drink while you wait for 15-20min. The service continued to be excellent though out our stay and the girls behind the bar were incredibly accommodating and hard working!Food was superb! I recommend the padron peppers and the squid ink rice and crab meat!

photos.caption: Photo of Jose - London, United Kingdom. Squid ink rice and crab meat

bO_4vyqL60iu4Vvqbxv6cQ.text: We showed up here around 7 on a Monday night on our last night in London. The place was completely packed but the host greeted us and told us he was having the best day of his life. And it really felt like he was, even in the middle of a packed restaurant and here we are trying to add to his workload. He offered to let us stand at the counter and start ordering food and then once a seat opened, they'd move us over. We ordered the tortilla, the croquettas, and the potatas bravas. Let me say, it was one of the cheapest meals we had in London and was also one of the best meals we had. The service was friendly and fast. They couldn't have been nicer to us. We had meant to visit last year but they don't take reservations so we never wanted to wait for a table so luckily for us, we did make it this time and had a great night. This place is very close to the underground and a bunch of pubs in case there is a wait. We even got some tortilla to go after we ate the first plate they brought out. Eat here.

tg-tzD56whPFw9XM1UHJkw.text: I've been walking past here for a year now assuming that this was the waiting area and that there is an underground part to it. I was wrong. It is a tee is tiny space, almost bar like, with lots of places to perch, definitely not suitable for large groups. And that is why this place is cool. I think where people go wrong with tapas is when there are too many people and someone (possibly an ordering novice) takes over ordering and under orders. With a small place like this, where quite literally a party of three is verging on the 'too big' side, it's hard to under order as you will probably want one of everything and it's easier not to be polite in a two or a three. Rule of thumb: start with the tomato bread, knockout some of those initial worms, then work your way through as much as possible. Menu changes regularly but there will be jamon, croquettes, tortilla, the potato bravas with aioli, something with chorizo, maybe even a bocadillo (conveniently named slider for your English benefit). Wine list is awesome: start with a sherry. Staff are just as awesome- truly hospitality professionals with personality, enjoying what they do. See you in the window!

photos.caption: Photo of Jose - London, United Kingdom. Chickpeas, morcilla, chorizo
Photo of Jose - London, United Kingdom. Croquets, pain tomate, shrimp frittes

nhnbh6xoOlI50xv9i6VJNA.text: Pleasantly uncomfortable and friendly corner "bistrot", with prices from the hights of the City.If you are really home sick, I suggest you buy a Ryanair return to Madrid and splurge for the week-end. You might still have spare change !Oh-Kay, it's a 4* but probably won't trek to South London(bridge) again for the pleasure...

yqMnt1eJECauo6iqUEWung.text: What I love about tapas is that it comes thick and fast. It matches the buzz of a Spanish environment and its atmosphere, and this is what makes @jose_pizarro one of if not THE best Spanish bars to eat in London. Tight, cosy & authentic space. Certainly my favourite tho Barrafina is battling it close as if it was Ronaldo vs Messi for the Ballon d'or (again).I did want the pluma, oh THAT pluma; looking out for it as I peaked over her diners toward the specials board, but found the ibérico pork fillet as a great substitute. Melt in the mouth goodness. Could easily eat two plates of these.Was gasping for some King Prawns a la plancha like I had last time, but wasn't on there so ended up for going for a fish. Served medium rare which I have never seen before. Was asked if I wanted it cooked more and I did. Better cooked through IMO.I also shared some Spanish croquettes. Today is the turn of spinach to be the hero, which is unbelievably moist with that cheese inside.(Updated review - 19th Nov '15)

photos.caption: Photo of Jose - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Jose - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Jose - London, United Kingdom

POJNeYUqugNZpwOCzR-_iA.text: Food is very tasty and when you see what they have on that board you will experience hard times in deciding!! Definitely to try the peppers and the steak with shallots! no booking, but it gets very busy, so don't go if you are a large group!

o5X8SdSXejPbgdwa8IqJQw.text: Jose tapas had very tasty food, very tasty food indeed, but to me it was a place that tried a little too hard to create a spanish atmosphere in London. First the good:Great red wine- the second and third choices on the menu were both good recomendations from the waitress, with the second choice, the Granache, our favorite (£4.5-£5 per glass).  Usually my wife and I dont esepcailly enjoy spanish wine.  Croquetas- crispy on the outside while perfectly fluffy on the inside.  Definitely melt-in-your-mouth (£6.5)Tortilla- with courgettes and some type of drizzle.  Hardy (£4.5)Pan con Tomate- hard to dissapoint (£3.5)The only thing that put us off was the lack of seating- there was ample standing room, but the place seemed to only distribute seats to about half the places.  We asked to wait until we could get seats to eat, but they seemed to want to rush us out by 'recomending' multiple times to order as soon as possible.  We did not want to pay 4x the price of similar food in Spain and be rushed out.  Seems the exact antithesis of the spanish way.  The waitresses were nice after this initial unpleasantness, and especially once we got seats.  Overall, a fun place, but will probably not return.

photos.caption: Photo of Jose - London, United Kingdom. Pan con tomate, tortilla, croquetas

PNFTmVbCu7s1SzxeNp4Gcg.text: been here a few times and had to stand as it was so busy, but it was worth it.  staff is friendly and the food was worth the wait.  the prawns and fried green peppers were amazing.  prices are reasonable as well.  lively atmosphere

gKvJt9oR--7a5my5oW3V_A.text: José is the small and simple cava and tapas bar from José Pizzaro who also runs a more upscale (still rather casual though) down the road on Bermondsey Street. José is in a way too close to where I live as it is always tempting to stop by for a glass (or bottle) of cava and some of the lovely tapas. It is almost always crowded here but people do not tend sit for long so often the wait is not that bad and with a glass of sparkling in the hand time moves faster.There are usually three or four sparkling by the glass and a few reds and whites as well. The wines are decently priced but perhaps not cheap, the on-going gentrification of Bermondsey Street has meant that prices are moving up. Food is excellent, the menu is not fixed (written on two black boards behind the bar and as things run out they are crossed off the board) but a few things can almost always be found there so there will be some excellent Spanish cheeses as well as Jamon and chorizo. My favorite is however without a doubt the flavorful Pluma Iberico (or when that is not on the menu the Secreto Iberico). Service is always friendly and considering that it is always packed things move along smoothly. I also do like the fact that they do not automatically include service on the bill - more places should do that.So to summarize my favorite tapas place in London (and where I can likely be found on a Thursday, Friday or Saturday and any other day I may happen to me home).

w_xo9BFlZ6I8Tk9kGEj85w.text: Great tapas place not too pricey, delicious food but hats off to the staff for great service. Definitely recommend and will be returning.

TUHR1mBZlYSChoXWb3uOFQ.text: OMG this place is outstanding!  I went here 2 night in a row, which I never do on vacation, but it was seriously that good!  It's a tiny little place, but the servers do a really good job at getting people in and to tables or the bar.  I tried several different things but my favorite by far was the fried goat cheese with honey!!! It was amazing!  The only negative was I felt like they had really small pours of wine, more than other spots in London.  That was disappointing, but not enough to not return.  I will be recommending this Tapas bar everyone that is spending time in London. Cheers!

cdwvSa05fcLyyDFnekiTWA.text: First off, I'm not generally a tapas guy--nothing against the taste but just not normally into small portions or sharing food =) ...but fast forward to this dining trip, and I may have to change my mind about tapas. This place was simply amazing! We ate in a couple of rounds, ordering first the Jamón (OMG), Patatas Bravas (yum!), and Bread w/ Tomato (simple but succulent)--all of these blew my mind. Our 2nd round consisted of the fried calamari, chorizo sausages, and fried (really sautéed) peppers--again, all delicious. To accompany our meal, we ordered a bottle of rosé, which paired perfectly with all of our selections.I didn't know it when we came here, but the restaurant is owned by celebrated Spanish chef José Pizarro. I'll definitely be buying his book on Spanish cooking! ...and waiting for the day he brings his stuff to NYC!
